Award.AwardTitle: DMREF/Collaborative Research: Computationally Driven Targeting of Advanced Thermoelectric Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
The discovery of thermoelectric materials is the critical bottleneck limiting the widespread use of thermoelectric generators for energy harvesting. To date, the search for such materials has been challenging due to the multitude of conflicting property requirements that must be simultaneously satisfied. The proposed research addresses these challenges through a high-throughput search for materials, enabled by the continued improvements in large-scale computing and the development of a thermoelectric performance metric suitable for high-throughput calculations. High accuracy measurements of electronic structure and majority carrier transport properties will be used to validate the calculated descriptors. In support of these efforts, rapid experimental validation approaches for theory-predicted thermoelectric materials will be developed. On-the-fly data mining of the resulting experimental/theoretical property database will yield material-property relationships pointing to new target materials. The resulting techniques and software tools will be well-documented and open-access. The resulting property database will serve as the seed for a long-term central, open repository for thermoelectric materials. This research program lays the groundwork for a new, computationally driven, paradigm in thermoelectric material research.

****Non-Technical Abstract****
The development of advanced thermoelectric materials could have a profound impact on the nation's energy portfolio. Solar thermoelectric generators and waste heat recovery could provide a significant fraction of our electricity needs. This program will lead to the development and dissemination of a transformative methodology for the realization of new thermoelectric materials, which can be extended to other materials sub-disciplines. High throughput electronic structure calculations of known earth-abundant compounds will provide the critical descriptors to identify new materials. The veracity of these calculations will be continuously tested through experimental measurements. Adaptive data mining will be used to extract structure-property trends and organically grow the material database. In doing so, a new generation of students (community college, undergraduate, graduate, post-doc) will be trained, which are conversant with both theoretical and experimental approaches to science by immersing them in a fully integrated research program. This effort extends beyond the core students in the research group through workshops focused on integrated theory/experiment approaches to thermoelectric materials and working in a "big-data" environment. A suite of K-12 and community college outreach programs targets the recruitment of underrepresented groups in STEM. These innovative programs include teacher training modules, after school programs, and summer research opportunities for community college students.

This award is supported by the Divisions of Materials Research (DMR), of Mathematical Sciences (DMS), and of Computer and Network Systems (CNS).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long-term research goal is to develop a robust computational and data mining toolkit to target advanced thermoelectric materials. Within the scope of this collaborative project across three institutions, our team has focused primarily on applying data-mining techniques to the electronic structure calculations to reveal structure-property trends within semiconductors and adaptively suggest materials for computational investigation. 

We have developed the TE Design Lab (www.tedesignlab.org), a thermoelectrics-focused virtual laboratory that contains calculated thermoelectric properties as well as performance rankings based on a metric that combines ab initio calculations and modeled electron and phonon transport to offer a reliable assessment of the intrinsic material properties that govern the thermoelectric figure of merit zT. Another useful component of TE Design Lab is the suite of interactive web-based tools that enable users to mine the raw data and unearth new structure–property relations. Examples that illustrate this utility are presented. With the goal of establishing a close partnership between experiments and computations, TE Design Lab also offers resources to analyze raw experimental thermoelectric data and contribute them to the open access database. The TEDL database currently hosts 61 computed attributes of 2303 compounds. Our TEDL website has been visited by more than four thousand unique users from all over the world, and our TEDL article has been cited 30 times.

Our initial investigation has revealed the significant challenges of data mining thermoelectric data due to the complexity and high dimensionality of thermoelectric materials as well as the severe data sparsity. As such, global pattern analysis did not work well. We then focused on local pattern analysis, which aimed to identify and leverage data patterns in local neighborhoods. We worked on identifying the key contributing features for compound classification of lattice thermal conductivity using decision tree and the gini metric as a reverse engineering method. In addition, we have developed different techniques for sparse matrix approximation, including the use of local clusters, combination of local and global information, as well as performance stability analysis and learning rate adaptation. We have also developed a hierarchical context-aware anomaly detection method using unsupervised learning, and a multimodal anomaly classification method. These methods leverage local similarity across multimodal data, which would be applicable for thermoelectric materials data.  

We have developed a trainable similarity function that jointly captures composition similarity, structure similarity, and chemistry similarity. We have also developed a framework that utilizes the trainable similarity function as kernel functions in the kernelized machine learning method kNN (k-nearest neighbor). We have conducted detailed analysis and experiments using two different data sets and three different attributes. Our proposed kNN method with trainable similarity function achieves the best performance (i.e., lowest RMSE: Root Mean Square Error) across all six scenarios, outperforming state-of-the-art methods in the literature. Besides the significantly improved performance, the key benefits of our proposed method include (1) the similarity function is automatically trainable and can easily adapt to different data sets and different attributes; (2) our method is robust against skewed data distribution of available compounds; and (3) the models can be easily re-trained when new compounds and more data become available, thus enabling continued improvement of the modeling performance.

The MGI (Materials Genome Initiative) philosophy brings together scientists from different disciplines to work on the same problem in a closed loop setting. These include theory, computations, experiment and data. Without the MGI approach, the interaction between different disciplines would be one directional; this would occur mainly through scientific publications, implying much slower exchange and transfer of knowledge and much longer time per theory-computation-synthesis-characterization cycle. Therefore, the MGI plays an invaluable role in accelerating the exchange of knowledge between complementary disciplines, which, as a result, accelerates materials discovery and design. Also, MGI offers unique opportunities for young researchers (graduate students and postdocs) to develop multidisciplinary expertise.
